section.title: Managing and Monitoring JAIN SLEE Container
View JAIN SLEE Server Version and State
section.para: At the top, under the summary section the Type, Version and State of the server is shown.

section.title: Monitor JAIN SLEE Availability over time
section.para: Accessing the MONITOR tab will display a graph showing the availability of the server over time.

section.title: View installed JAIN SLEE Components
section.para: Accessing the INVENTORY tab will display a table presenting the installed components and deployable units.

note.title: Components deployed outside &MANAGEMENT.PLATFORM;
note.para: If components are installed outside &MANAGEMENT.PLATFORM;, after &MANAGEMENT.PLATFORM; Agent is started, the list of installed components will not be updated in a real-time .
For performance reasons, &MANAGEMENT.PLATFORM; servers sub-components (such as Deployable Units, Resource Adaptors, SBBs and Services in SLEE) are checked for changes every 24 hours.

section.para: To force a service discovery, there are two options:

listitem.para: In the &MANAGEMENT.PLATFORM; web app, right-click the root item (Platform) of the JAIN SLEE Server and select Execute OperationManual Autodiscovery. Select Yes in Detailed Discovery and run the discovery by clicking the SCHEDULE button.
In the &MANAGEMENT.PLATFORM; agent console, run a full discovery, by issuing the following command:> discovery -f

section.title: Install/Uninstall JAIN SLEE Deployable Units
section.para: In the INVENTORY tab, you can Install/Uninstall JAIN SLEE Deployable Units.

section.title: Install JAIN SLEE Deployable Units
section.para: In order to install a deployable unit, select DeployableUnits on the Create New: option box and click OK, the following page will be displayed:

figure.title: Installing a Deployable Unit with &MANAGEMENT.PLATFORM; JAIN SLEE Plugin.

textobject.para: Installing a Deployable Unit with &MANAGEMENT.PLATFORM; JAIN SLEE Plugin.

section.para: Click the UPLOAD FILE... button, a new browser window will be displayed in which you can upload the JAIN SLEE Deployable Unit. Click Add..., select the Deployable Unit to be installed, click Upload to confirm and close the browser window.

warning.para: Depending on your web browser, you may be asked to resend the information. Please accept it. Google Chrome browser may not support this operation!

section.para: Back on the main window for installing the DU, select either to do a persistent deploy (copy file to deploy folder) or (simply call install on the DU).

important.title: Persistent vs JMX Deployment
important.para: When doing a persistent deployment, further installation actions are automatically performed by the &THIS.PLATFORM; JAIN SLEE Deployer. If the DU is not deployed in a persistent way (JMX), component installation actions (such as Resource Adaptor entities creation, activation, Service activation) should be performed manually.

section.para: To confirm the deployment, click CREATE. If successful, a confirmation message will be displayed.

section.title: Uninstall JAIN SLEE Deployable Units
section.para: To uninstall a deployable unit, simply check the desired installed deployable unit on the INVENTORY tab and press DELETE. A confirmation dialog be displayed.

figure.title: Uninstalling a Deployable Unit with &MANAGEMENT.PLATFORM; JAIN SLEE Plugin.

textobject.para: Uninstalling a Deployable Unit with &MANAGEMENT.PLATFORM; JAIN SLEE Plugin.

important.title: Persistent vs JMX Undeployment
important.para: The undeployment of a persistent or a JMX based DU is automatically detected. In the first scenario (persistent), when a file is deleted from the deploy directory. In the JMX context (non-persistent deployment), where the uninstall command is called on the DU, requiring prior uninstalling actions (eg: remove RA Links and Entities) to have already been performed.

section.title: Start/Stop/Shutdown &THIS.PLATFORM; JAIN SLEE Server
section.para: Under the OPERATIONS tab, an operation for Changing the JAIN SLEE container state can be found: Change Slee State.
Clicking on the operation, a new pane opens so the parameters can be selected:

listitem.para: start - Changes SLEE State to RUNNING state.
stop - Changes SLEE State to STOPPED state.
shutdown - Completely shuts down SLEE. The server must be in the Stopped state before you can transition to Shutdown.

note.para: Similar to most operations on &MANAGEMENT.PLATFORM;, this operation can be scheduled for a later time, have a defined timeout and/or include additional notes.

section.para: Clicking on the SCHEDULE executes (if Immediately is selected) or schedules the operation. After being executed, it is shown in HISTORY, Completed Operations. Clicking on its name shows the result(s).

section.title: List All Activity Contexts
section.para: For monitoring purposes, it is possible to have all JAIN SLEE Activity Contexts listed. This can be done with List all Activity Context operation, in OPERATIONS tab.
This action takes no parameters.

note.para: This operation can be scheduled for a later time, have a defined timeout and/or include additional notes.

section.para: Clicking on the SCHEDULE executes (if Immediately is selected) or schedules the operation. After being executed, it is shown in HISTORY, Completed Operations. Clicking on its name shows the result(s).

section.title: Query Activity Context Liveness
section.para: In order to clean dead Activities, you can query Activity Context for their liveness. This can be done using Query Activity Context Liveness operation, in OPERATIONS tab.
This action takes no parameters.

note.para: This operation can be scheduled for a later time, have a defined timeout and/or include additional notes.

section.para: Clicking on the SCHEDULE executes (if Immediately is selected) or schedules the operation. After being executed, it is shown in HISTORY, Completed Operations. Clicking on its name shows the result(s).

section.title: Change Container Logging Configuration
section.para: It is possible to configure JAIN SLEE container logging according to your needs. This can be done using Change Global Logging Profile operation, in OPERATIONS tab. There are three levels available:

listitem.para: DEFAULT: Regular logging, at INFO level, displaying most user-related messages;
DEBUG: More verbose logging, mostly using DEBUG/TRACE level, displaying message of interest for developers;
PRODUCTION: Low verbosity and async logging, mostly in WARN level, for systems in production so that logging does impact performance.

note.para: This operation can be scheduled for a later time, have a defined timeout and/or include additional notes.

section.para: Clicking on the SCHEDULE executes (if Immediately is selected) or schedules the operation. After being executed, it's shown in HISTORY, Completed Operations. Clicking on its name shows the result(s).

note.para: This changes the whole container logging configuration, so it will affect also logging for other running applications in the container, besides JAIN SLEE.

section.title: Edit Container Logging Configurations
section.para: It is possible to customize the above mentioned logging configurations, or also the currently in use container logging configuration. To perform this action, two operations must be performed.
First, to retrieve the current logging configuration, go to the OPERATIONS tab, then Get Logging Profile Configuration operation. One of the following options can be used:

listitem.para: CURRENT: will retrieve the logging configuration currently in use by the container (can be a custom one);
DEFAULT: will retrieve the DEFAULT logging configuration;
DEBUG: will retrieve the DEBUG logging configuration;
PRODUCTION: will retrieve the PRODUCTION logging configuration;

section.para: After completion, it is shown in HISTORY, Completed Operations. Clicking on the name shows the result, which is the actual logging configuration.
The result of the operation can be edited in your favorite XML editor as required.

warning.title: Logging configuration size limitation
warning.para: Note that the XML file has a limit of 2000 characters. Consequently, do not exceed this limit

section.para: Once you finish editing the XML, the Update Logging Profile Configuration operation can be used to update the logging configuration contents.
Select the desired configuration to be updated from the similar list as presented above, and paste the edited contents in the Contents field of the operation.

note.para: This operation can be scheduled for a later time, it can have defined timeout and/or include additional notes.

section.para: Clicking on the SCHEDULE executes (if Immediately is selected) or schedules the operation. After being executed, it is shown in HISTORY, Completed Operations. Clicking on its name shows the result(s).

note.para: Editing the DEFAULT, DEBUG or PRODUCTION configurations does not apply them, even if they are currently being used. It only edits the configuration template. To edit the configuration being used, select the CURRENT configuration.

section.title: View Event Router Statistics
section.para: The &MANAGEMENT.PLATFORM; JAIN SLEE platform enables you to gather statistics on the Event Router. Under the OPERATIONS tab, in the View Event Router Statistics operation, you can view the statistics in table form.
The statistics can be filtered by the following levels:

listitem.para: Global: Shows the container global statistics for all executors and event types (eg: container's total number of events routed, activities mapped, etc.);
Executors: Shows the statistics per executor (eg: activities mapped per executor, average routing time per executor, idle time per executor, etc.);
Event Types: Shows the statistics for each event type deployed (eg: average routing time per event type, number of events of the type routed, etc.);

Executors and Event Types: Shows the combined statistics of Executors with Event Types (eg: number of events of some router per executor, average time for routing certain event types per executor, total time spent per executor routing certain event types, etc.);
All: All the above together.

note.para: The above operations can be scheduled for a later time, they can also have defined timeout and/or include additional notes.

section.para: Clicking on the SCHEDULE executes (if Immediately is selected) or schedules the operation. After being executed, it is shown in HISTORY, Completed Operations. Clicking on its name shows the result(s).

section.title: Managing Congestion Control
section.para: The &MANAGEMENT.PLATFORM; JAIN SLEE platform provides congestion control mechanisms to prevent the server from becoming unresponsive under very high load.
The following parameters are available for configuration and the correspondent set operations (CC-Set<parameter>) can be found under OPERATIONS tab:

listitem.para: MinFreeMemoryToTurnOn: The minimum memory (percentage) that should be available to turn on congestion control;
MinFreeMemoryToTurnOff: The minimum memory (percentage) that should be available to turn off congestion control;
PeriodBetweenChecks: The period in seconds to check if congestion control state should change. 0 means congestion control is off;
RefuseStartActivity: Defines if the start of activity should be refused, when congestion control is on;
RefuseFireEvent: Defines if the firing of an event should be refused, when congestion control is on;

note.para: These operations can be scheduled for a later time and have defined timeout and/or include additional notes.

section.para: Clicking on the SCHEDULE executes (if Immediately is selected) or schedules the operation. After being executed, it is shown in HISTORY, Completed Operations. Clicking on its name shows the result(s).
